3.64 Ha of cotton destroyed.

sources: Report on Destruction Caused by El-Nino Rains in Pallisa District
comments:
A four-classroom block at Abia Primary School was de-roofed.
27.52 Ha of cassava, maize, cotton and sweet potatoes were destroyed.

A two-classroom block was destroyed in one school and in another, a six-classroom block was damaged.
Other sub-counties affected included: Agule, Butebo and Kamuge.
Villages affected incluled: Oboliso, Omotoi, Boliso, Bugwere, Nyakoi, Komollo B, Pasia, Kachaboi, Kachinga, Kasyebai,and  Boliso II.

A two-classroom block was destroyed in one school and in another, a six-classroom block was damaged.
Other sub-counties affected included: Kameke, Butebo and Kamuge.
Villages affected incluled: Oboliso, Omotoi, Boliso, Bugwere, Nyakoi, Komollo B, Pasia, Kachinga, Kachaboi, Kasyebai and Boliso II.
A total of 44 hoseholds were affected. This figure is captured in the Pallisa District, Kameke Sub-county data card.

A two-classroom block was destroyed in one school and in another, a six-classroom block was damaged.
Other sub-counties affected included: Agule, Kameke and Kamuge.
Villages affected incluled: Oboliso, Omotoi, Boliso, Bugwere, Nyakoi, Komollo B, Pasia, Kachinga, Kachaboi, Kasyebai and Boliso II.
A total of 44 hoseholds were affected. This figure is captured in the Pallisa District, Kameke Sub-county data card.

A two-classroom block was destroyed in one school and in another, a six-classroom block was damaged.
Other sub-counties affected included: Agule, Butebo and Kameke.
Villages affected incluled: Oboliso, Omotoi, Boliso, Bugwere, Nyakoi, Komollo B, Pasia, Kachinga, Kachaboi, Kasyebai and Boliso II.
A total of 44 hoseholds were affected. This figure is captured in the Pallisa District, Kameke Sub-county data card.

sources: letter Ref: COU/201/2 from District Chairperson, Pallisa
comments:
Many people wre displaced as their homes were destroyed.
Several acres of crops were destroyed, resulting into food shortage.
The District Disaster Committee was to compile a list of the affected families and the extent of the damage at household level to be ready by 5/11/2010 but no report was attached to the letter.

sources: letter Ref: COU/201/2 from District Chairperson, Pallisa
comments:
Many people wre displaced as their homes were destroyed.
Several acres of crops were destroyed, resulting into food shortage.
The District Disaster Committee was to compile a list of the affected families and the extent of the damage at household level to be ready by 5/11/2010 but no report was attached to the letter.

sources: Brief on Disaster Situation in Uganda dated 11/03/02
letter Ref: COU/201/2 from District Chairperson, Pallisa
comments:
Many people wre displaced as their homes were destroyed.
Several acres of crops were destroyed, resulting into food shortage.
The District Disaster Committee was to compile a list of the affected families and the extent of the damage at household level to be ready by 5/11/2010 but no report was attached to the letter.

others: Many domestic animals and birds were killed.
sources: letter Ref: MSW/01/09 from Minister of State for water dated 19/10/09
comments:
All the gardens in the area were destroyed.
Starvation and health related threats have been reported.
Affected villages       No.of Destroyed houses 
1. Buluba                   5
2. Nandere                  3
3. Bulabya                  6
4. Katyaime                 2
5. Mavungo                  2

sources: Article in the Online Daily Monitor: Floods displace 3,000 in Nebbi by Patrick Okaba and Felix Worom Okello
comments:
The heavy rains caused River Ora to burst its banks sending water gushing into the low-lying areas of Wadelai Sub-county.
Total number of affected villages is 20.
Ojigo Road has been rendered impassable, making residents of Pakwinyo Parish unable to access health centres and schools.

sources: letter Ref: 01/02/2010 from the Head Teacher Oturgang Girls' Primary School
comments:
The strom blew off the roof of a four-classroom block that was accomodating the infant classes of two streams  P1 A & B and P2 A & B.
The pupils affected were between the ages of 6-9 yrs.
Both subcounties of Sisiyi and Buluganya had 26 deaths and many affected.

sources: Cabinet paper by min of state disaster preparedness dated 26/05/10 ref: opm/dm/92

comments:
Crops and seeds have been affected, resulting to food shortages.
Malnutrition cases especially among children, the elderly, pregnant mothers and people with disabilities have increased.
Limited acreage of food crops are under cultivation due to the polonged dry spell.
Cassava, the staple food is available in isolated localities in Panyago and Wadelai Sub-counties.
Increased theft of food stuff (in the fields and households) as well as livestock is rampant.
Areas in Jonam and parts of Padyere Counties continued to experience the dry spell.

sources: Letter from the LC III Chairperson dated 9/9/2005
comments: Mukimba village was totally affected.
Classrooms, toilets and staff accomodation were destroyed. Information provided were for schools only.

Affected crops were: cassava, cotton, beans, maize
A resident lost 6 acres of beans and cotton.
Most affected areas were: Docha, Kapyani II, Kapyani Central

sources: Assessment report by OPM dated 20/05/11 by Pamel
comments: According to the rapid assessmentreport, the sub counties affected include muyembe, bukhalu, nabbongo, sironko tc, bwikonge, bunambutye and butanga. There areno specific parishes highlighted.

Affected crops were: cassava, cotton, beans, maize
A resident lost 6 acres of beans and cotton.
Most affected areas were: Docha, Kapyani II, Kapyani Central
The figure of affected people (400) was captured in the Buseta Sub-county, Kasasira Paris data card.

A total of 102 pit latrines were destroyed. The followingacres of crops were damaged; maize 196, bananas 98, potatoes 45, g/nuts 82, tomatoes 20 and onions 25. 12 heads of cattle also died in the floods.

In Lwebitakuli subcounty, Kabale parish, drought severly affected maize to the extend that no harvest was made. Other crops affected were; Beans, cassava, sweetpotatoes and coffee which dried up completely. The acreage of crops affected was not reflected in the data.

others: Latrines destroyed, crops and livestock affected.
comments: The parishes affected are not reflected in the report. Also destroyed other crops included; maize 152, bananas 55, potatoes 25. 8 goats and 9 cows.

sources: Report from Min. of State for Disaster Preparedness, Relief and Refugees
comments: Classrooms, toilets and some staff houses were destroyed.
Classrooms, toilets and some staff accomodation were destroyed. Information provided were on schools only.
Also affected are 105 hectares of maize, 320 hectatres of bananas, 55 hectatres of Irish potatoes, 65 hectatres of tomatoes. Poultry 102 chicken and livestock 55 goats.

15 villages have been affected.
Access to boreholes has been affected making residents resort to using water from the flooded areas which could pose as a health risk.
Crops destroyed include: cassava, millet, sorghum, simsim, rice, cotton, maiza, sugarcane, groundnuts, potatoes.

15 villages have been affected.
Access to boreholes has been affected making residents resort to using water from the flooded areas which could pose as a health risk.
Crops destroyed include: cassava, millet, sorghum, simsim, rice, cotton, maiza, sugarcane, groundnuts, potatoes.
566.56 ha of crops destroyed (figure has been captured in the Wadelai Sub-county, Pakwinyo Parish data card.

others: Damaged crops, poultry and displaced people.
comments: The damage in this sub county was severe as reflected here; the damaged included 50 hectares of millet and rice, 105 hectares of ground nuts, 42 hectares of tomatoes and 520 hectares of sun flower. Livestock 26 cows and 624 goats died. Poultry 2,030 chicken.
The floods caused damaged to other crops like 106 hectares of maize and 112 hectares of bananas was destroyed.

In Bwikhonge sub-county, two parishes were affected by floods: Bulumela and buwabwala. In Bulumela, the villages affected were Buwesa, Bunekibo Bulumera, Buwalusati, Bumotsofi. In Buwabwala parish, the villages affected were Bukhaloi, Buwabwala, Lusiango, Byaka, Bunabalayo, Buwanyama. A total of 868 house holds affected with a total population of 5213
There was massive destruction of buildings and crops. In addition to beans, 202 hecatres of maize and 312 hectares of bananas were damaged.

2 teachers and 2 pupils were injured.
A classroom block was destroyed.

Properties were destroyed.
Latrines have collapsed, forcing residents to use the bushes which could pose as a health risk as there is a likelihood of water-borne disease outbreaks such as cholera and bilharzia.
The residents have been advised to dig a channel that could pump water into the lake.
In Bufumbula Parish, the villages affected is Buwalusati. Atotal household of 1346 with a total population of 7548 have been displaced and are have taken refuge in the Churches and Schools.
In addition to beans, crops like maize and bananas were also damaged seriously by the floods.

others: Roads and crops were severely affected.

comments: In Bulumbali Town Council, the Parishes affected were not highlighted in the report but a total of 375 households with a total population of 1500 people were affected by the floods

comments: Bumakhase school was shattered by floods. A toatal of 755 students and 8 teachers were affected.

Cassava, mango trees and many other trees were uprooted and destroyed.

Atiak Health Centre IV was destroyed.Damages included:
* The newly built out-patient ward had its roof blown off.
* The old out-patient ward and theatre were partly blown off.
* 5 staff houses were damaged.
* The roof of the corridor linking the maternity ward to the theatre ws blown away.
* The latrine roof and solar panels were blown away but not destroyed.
* The drug store as well as an assortment of drugs and equipment was destroyed.
* 4 waiting/screening centres, the roof to the isolation ward and in-patient ward were blown off.

Affected Primary Schools included:
1. Pupwonya Primay School - P7 classroom was partly destroyed as well as the headteacher's office,house, water tank and gutter.
2. Olya P7 School - 3 classroom roofs were blown off, as well as 2 latrine roofs, a store and 9 teachers' grass thatched houses. (The H/M submitted a seperate letter reporting the destruction of the school buildings by the storm)
3. Okidi P7 School - 1 classroom and the headteacher's office roofs were blown off.
4. Kurutu P7 School - a latrine roof was blown away.
5. Lwani Memorial School - 1 classroom roof was blown away.
6. Atiak Nursery School - 1 classroon roof was blown away

sources: Letter dated 22/11/2010 from the MP and the CAO
comments:
The main crops that were affected were banana plantations, cassava, potatoes and jack fruits.
Also hit was Buwanda village in Lwabenge Sub-county.
In Kalungu Sub-county, Kibisi Parish affected villages were: Kibisi, Kateera, Kinyerere A, Namagoma
The most affected village was Buwanda.
Destruction of crops by the hailstorm was recorded.
Crops such as Beans, maize, cassava, tomatoes, bananas, coffee, tea and millet were destroyed.

sources: Brief on Disaster Situation in Uganda dated 11/03/02

comments: A number of crops were destroyed.

sources: Letter Ref: UPDF/MABS/HC/009 from H/Teacher Masindi Army Boarding Primary School
comments:
The fire started around 10:00am and gutted a boys' dormitory, destroying alot of property.
The problem at hand was that there was lack of accomodation facilities like mattresses, beds, blankets, sheets, basins, jerrycans, clothing and slippers.

A major road linking DR Congo and Koboko district was rendered impassable by the floods.
Apa bridge was destroyed.
Household items were also destroyed.
Affected crops included: vegetables, rice gardens and sugarcane fields.

Affected area covers approximately 150 sq. meters between Oraba, Wamale and Maniko roads.
Household Property was completely destroyed.
The 191 affected people have been displaced with some sleeping at nearby Nyarilo Primary School and others with relatives.

sources: Letter Ref: MS/OVP/020 from Minister of State, Office of the Vice President
comments:
Over 70% of the district households survive on one meal a day, 20% have no hope of a meal in a day. This is not improved by the increase in food prices.

Increased food related theft cases, domestic problems, environmental degradation, the crime rate, food related sicknesses such as anaemia, general body weakness and malnutrition have all been recorded.

The most affected sub-county was Lobule with a population of almost 80,000 people.

sources: Report on Epidemic in Agago District.
comments:
Description of cause: Presents with a history of headache, dizziness, general body weakness, abdominal pain, nose bleeding, blood from mouth and anus, fever, generalised tonic clonic convulsions. Patients die within 48-72 hours of onset of symptoms.
There was recorded inadequate staff from Agago's health department, inadequate abulance services coupled with bad road conditions.
The neighbouring Abim District had also been affected.
6 sub-counties in Agago District had been affected.
An investigation team of 5 people visited the sites and investigated the deaths. Lab analysis was done at the Central Public Health Laboratory in Kampala and The Uganda Virus Research Institute, Entebbe. Results were not out as of the date this report was submitted.

sources: Letter Ref: COU/106/1 from District Chairperson-Kibaale
comments:
4 roads were affected.

1. KISSURA-KAMAGALI via MPEEFU SUB-COUNTY FEEDER ROAD (15KM)
The road has been badly rutted and damaged by the rains. Fish fridged vehicles no longer collect fish from Kobushera to Kampala. People in the catchment area of the feeder road are cut off from the rest of the District. Cost damages- USH 185,885,271

2. KAKUMIRO-NLWEYO via NKOOKO ROAD (64.4KM)
The stretch between Mpasaana and Nalweyo (21.1km) has rutted badly and some swamps are flooded and culverts broken due to the El-nino rains. Heavy trucks can't access the area and buy farmers' produce.
At Kamusenene, underlying rocks are being exposed by water erosion.
Cost damages-USH 134,105,014

3. KIBAALE-PAACWA ROAD (45.9KM)
Last stretch from Bugwara junction to Paacwa Trading centre junction is badly rutted and swamps at Kamuziizi, Nyakasala and Rugaaga are flooded.
Stretch between Bugwara and Kiryanga Trading Centre has been vert slippery along steep hills because it is not gravelled. No vehicles can access the area when it rains.
The stretch locks R.C.C lines particularly across the swamps/streams and sags.
Places between Kibaale and Bugwara which are not gravelled like Mutunguru junction,Kisalizi Trading Centre, before and after Mbaya-Kyebando,Bagoya swamp,Kasimbi Trading Centre, Kitoolo Primary School and before Bugwara Trading Centre urgently require gravelling for El-nino has badly rutted them.
Cost damages-USH 148,55,353

4. MUHORO-NDAIGA via KYATEREKERA FEEDER ROAD (20KM)
From Muhoro, end of gravelled stretch, there are pot-holes and ruts.
The remaining road from Kisuura-Lubiri is not gravelled and badly rutted by the rains along the hills.
Cost of damages-USH 128,859,456
Heavy rain caused damage to crops and property.

sources: Letter Ref: mos/Lir/44, MP West Budama South Constituency
comments: Floods led to displacement of people and subsequent ressetlement in schools. Roads were also washed away. Also flooded were, gardens, homesteads, water sources and pit latrines. Some of the resultant effect includes outbreak of waterborn deseases such as Cholera, bilharzia and diahorea. Wild life also migrated from their habitat to proximity of human settlements resulting into crop destruction, property and life.

comments: Damage was mostly on physical structures.

others: Domestic animals and grinding mill house was destroyed.
comments: A number of crops were also destroyed by the landslide.

others: A few gardens were also swept.
1 bridge was destroyed by the floods.
Motor cycle was washed away by the water,
comments: A motorcycle rider and his paasenger drowned in the channel.

AFFECTED BRIDGES:
1. The main Bukwo Bridge in Bukwo Town Council on Kapchorwa-Suam Road, spanning 22m was reported s about to collapse due to flooding (Steel temporal mobile bridge.
2. The Siit River Bridge was damaged, spanning 12m (concrete bridge)
Other bridges that were washed away and totally destroyed along Bukwo River were:
3. Mission Foot Bridge (timber bridge)
4. Kabunwa Foot Bridge (timber bridge)
5. Sosho Foot Bridge (timber bridge)
6. Chemukun Foot Bridge (timber bridge)
7.Chetantan Foot Bridge (timber bridge)
Other bridges included those on Bukwo-Riwo to Greek River (Security Road). All made of concrete reinforced culverts.
8. Ngingin Bridge
9. Riwo Bridge
10.Aralam Bridge
11.Murwakunik Bridge
12.The Greek River Bridge (temporary) was damaged due to flooding and affected access to Bukwo District Headquarters, Nakapiripirit and other districts.

EDUCATION:
12 Schools were affected and some had collapsed VIP latrines. 
1. Tuel Primary School
2. Chesower Primary School
3. Kamet Primary School
4. Kortek Primary School
5. Mokoyon Primary School
6. Bukwo Primary School
7. Chekwasta Primary School
8. Senended Primary School
9. Kapyoyon Primary School
10.Suam Primary School
11.Kwirwot Primary School
12.Chesower Secondary School

HEALTH:
12 health centres were affected and as such have no drugs.
There is waterborne disease vulnerability. (cholera, typhoid, dysentry)

The Chebirbei Bridge along Amanang River was washed away due to the floods and this affected Bukwa and Suam Sub-counties which it linked.
People living in Yatui camp were displaced from Mt. Elgon National Park.
There is urgent need of tents/tarpaulins for housing, maize flour, beans, cooking utencils, hoes and pangas.

The Nyali GFS located in Chesower Sub-county was destroyed by the drought and floods. Affected people were 2,487.
Chesower Primary School and Chesower Secondary School were affected and also lost their VIP Latrines which collapsed.
Chesower Health Centre III was affected.There is waterborne disease vulnerability. (cholera, typhoid, dysentry)
194 households camped in Chesower Sub-county (population 498), due to dstroyed houses.
There is urgent need of tents/tarpaulins for housing, maize flour, beans, cooking utencils, hoes and pangas.
The Chepseikei GFS water scheme located in Kabei Sub-county was destroyed, affecting 5,230 people.
The Chebirbei Bridge along Amanang River was washed away due to the floods and this affected Bukwa and Suam Sub-counties which it linked.

sources: Letter Ref: MP46/04 from MP Usuk County
comments:
12 Secondary schools were affected with a population of 3500.
7000 people were affected in the Sub-counties of Usuk, Ongongoja, Katakwi and Ngariam. This data is captured in the Ongongoja Sub-County, Obwobwo Parish data card.

Situation has worsened due to water flowing from neighbouring districts of Napak, Amuria and beyond, filling up the water ways, destroying infrastructure, crops and grazing land.

ROAD SECTOR:
Affected roads included: Odoot-Olupe road, Orungo corner-Adakar
BRIDGES:
Ajeleki Bridge has become dangerous for vehicles to use.
The distance between Angisa and Magoro over Omunyo swamp (10km) is flooded, subsequently people have introduced canoes/boats over some sections.

EFFECTS ON COMMUNITY:
The situation has affected the community in that 8 couples have seperated.

EDUCATION:
The education sector has been affected by impassable roads.Teaching hours have greatly reduced, reduced attendance because of absentism and late coming.
17 Primary schools have water logged latrines whereas 4 schools are almost inaccessible.
Night commuters use school facilities thus straining them and posing a health threat to the school community and this arises from poor waste management and disposal.

WATER SECTOR:
Only one water source has remained uncontaminated due to water logging as revealed by the Water Department. Disinfection of all water sources has been carried out.

HEALTH SECTOR:
There has been increased incidences of malaria, cholera diarrhoea and guinea worms.
Angisa is cut off from the main land with no health facility.
Lalei and Katakwi Schools were affected.

Ngariam-Palam-Isingi Road has been affected.
The affected schools included: Amorwongora, Ngariam, Okwamomwar, Alengo, Odoot and Obuleagat
The Katakwi-Moroto Road was affected.

Affected roads included:Osuk-Ongongoja, Ongongoja-Obwobwo
Okocho school was affected.
Night commuting to Obulengorok Primary School was reported.

Affected roads: Magoro-Ngariam, Ngariam-Omodoi, Ngarriam-Palam, Isingi, Odoot Corner-Ngariam
Affected schools wee: Ocwiin, Opeum, Aodot, Olupe.
Affected roads are: Ngariam-Omodoi, Omodoi-Magoro
Affected roads: Toroma-Gweri-Soroti

Affected roads: Usuk-Ongonoja, Usuk-Amuria
Affected schools were: Taibong, Usuk Girls, Usuk Boys.

Affected roads: Magoro-Angisa, Magoro-Ngariam, Omodoi-Magoro
Omaria School was affected

sources: Report from Kabale District in File
comments:
The heavy downpour that lasted 9 hrs coupled with a spontaneous run off from all valleys within many water sheds converging to form huge water masses that moved along the valley carrying along stones, soil and boulders as well as destroying everyhting on the way and finally depositing everything at the bottom of the valley.
Alot of household property, stored food and merchandise in shops was destroyed.
Affected families were camped at church grounds and living with either relatives or friends.
Some of the affected crops were: irish potatoes, beans, cabbage, bananas, sorghum, sweet potatoes.
Boulders and silt have been deposited on roads and bridges resulting to inaccessibility of some areas such as Karorwa, Rukombe and Kabimbiri in Bukinda.
Muhanga-Rushebeya road was completely blocked and the bridge crossing at Kabimbiri was submerged and partly destroyed.
Destruction of landscape by formation of deep gullies, silt deposits, stones and boulders.
There is a likelihood of cholera, malnutrition, diarrhoea and malaria outbreaks.
The figures captured of the dead(1),affected(600), houses destroyed(30)injured(1),crops destroyed(500Ha) is inclusive of Nyabirerema, Muhanga, Kandago and Kyerero parishes.
The water source were destroyed plus some houses

The community is a fishing community. The garbage disposal is very poor in Katanga.People litter garbage everywhere including the drainage systems, water sources and their is a constant flow of sewerage from broken pipes. This flows adjacent to people's houses and restaurants.It attracts flies, which contaminate the food and water. Most families have poor hygiene and their children play in these sewerage systems.
Fire broke out at 7:40 pm on saterday 10/07/04 at Naalya S.S in a boys' dormitory. The affected students were given a week's holiday. Classroom were being use as dormitories.

sources: URCS Emergency Assessment report on floods in Sironko Branch, Bulambuli Sub Branch
comments: Rains caused rivers simu and sironko to burst their banks. Affected sub counties are: Muyembe, Bunambutye, Bukhalu, Sisiyi, Bulegeni. A similar flooding of the same magnitude occured in sironko in 1961. Affected crops are: Beans, Maize, Cassava, Matooke, Sweet potatoes. Education has been disrupted with a number of schools in the rural areas flooded and pit latrines collapsing as well as destruction of scholastic materials.Reported cases of severe malaria outbreaks and prediction of waterborne disease outbreaks. The poor state of the roads and the bridges made most of them totally impassable.

The El-nino caused destruction of food crops in gardens and what had already been harvested by 98%. 
Roads and bridges collapsed.
A state of emergency was declared by His Excellency the President.
The figures of those affected(3,000,000) and relocated (300,000)captured in the Agago District data card are inclusive of Pader, Kitgum, Lamwo, Gulu, Amuru, Nwoya, Lira, Oyam, Apac, Otuke, Amolatar, Moroto, Abim, Kotido, Kaabong and Nakapiripirit.

Most pit latrines have sunked down, resulting in sanitation crisis that may result into a cholera outbreak.

comments: All the districts of Karamoja; Kotido, Moroto, Nakapiripirit, Abim and Kaabong are facing famine. The food security situation in the North Eastern part of Karamoja deteriorated to famine level.

sources: Letter ref: OPM/DM/92 From Minister for Relief and Disaster Preparedness and Refugees
comments: The underlying cause of recurrent food shortages in this region is over dependence on seasonal foodcrops (maize, millet, simsim, groundnuts). There is need to grow semi-perennial food crops e.g cassava and yams. The march - May rain season presented inconsistent rainfall that affected production of maize, sweet potatoes, simsim and yams.
